CASE 32:
ASSESSMENT OF BEST INTERESTS
The family and friends of Alice are very unhappy with her care in a NHS neuro-disability
unit. Alice is 45 years old, and following viral encephalitis she has been left with severe neu-
rological impairment with no prospect of improvement. She cannot move or speak and is
entirely dependent on others for care. She is receiving clinically assisted nutrition and hydra-
tion. Alice was close to her father and sister and long-term partner. She does not have chil-
dren. Her family considers that she would not wish to carry on living in this condition and
that feeding should be withheld so she can die peacefully and with dignity.
Paul is 42. He has a severe learning disability and end-stage renal failure secondary to dia-
betes. Unless he receives an organ transplant, his life expectancy is significantly reduced. He
requires dialysis three times a week. He has a needle phobia and due to his learning disabili-
ties becomes physically aggressive and resists attempts by doctors to examine or treat him.
In order to carry out dialysis, he would require sedation by general anesthetic, which carries
inherent risks. His understanding of the situation is very limited.
Felicity is 55 years old and has a severe learning disability. She has localised cancer of the
uterus and her gynaecologist considers that without a hysterectomy the tumour will likely
metastasise and lead ultimately to her death.
Questions
• What factors should be considered in assessing the ‘best interests’ of an incompetent
adult patient?
• Who makes the decision about the patient’s best interests?
• What if the clinical team and the patient’s relatives disagree about what treatment is
in the patient’s best interests?
• Is it always in the patient’s best interests to do what the patient would most probably
have wanted if he had capacity?

data.vignette: Paul is 42 and has a severe intellectual disability. He has end-stage kidney failure from diabetes. He has been coming for hemodialysis, but he has a strong needle phobia and becomes physically aggressive when staff approach him. He cannot explain risks or alternatives, and he cannot consistently show understanding despite repeated attempts at adapted counseling. His support worker says Paul has always hated hospitals and keeps saying “no needles.” Without dialysis he is expected to decline and die, but with ongoing dialysis he could live for years. The only workable plan is dialysis under general anesthesia several times a week, with transport, fasting, and post-anesthesia confusion each time. His mother asks you to “do whatever keeps him alive.” The dialysis unit needs a decision today to book anesthesia support. Hospital policy permits either course under the best-interests standard.
data.choice_1: Proceed with regular dialysis using general anesthesia despite his resistance.
data.choice_2: Stop dialysis and transition to comfort-focused care with palliative support.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that makes one option medically dominant. Replace “Without dialysis he is expected to decline and die, but with ongoing dialysis he could live for years” with: “Without dialysis he will likely die in the near term; dialysis can prolong life but would require repeated anesthesia/sedation with significant burdens and risks.” Replace “The only workable plan is dialysis under general anesthesia” with “One feasible plan the unit can provide is dialysis with anesthesia/sedation support,” so stopping dialysis remains clinically defensible rather than ‘no option.’ Avoid implying objective superiority; keep consequences qualitative.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or condense operational details unless they drive the ethical burden. E.g., compress “transport, fasting, and post-anesthesia confusion each time” to “repeated peri-procedural distress and recovery time.” Add missing essentials that make the dilemma evaluable: (1) explicitly state he lacks decision-making capacity for dialysis decisions after adapted assessment; (2) clarify who is the legally authorized surrogate/guardian (mother vs court-appointed guardian) and whether there is any advance directive; (3) briefly state what less-restrictive measures have already been attempted (behavioral desensitization, topical anesthetic, anxiolysis, staff familiarization) so the choice is not ‘try standard steps first.’

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Dialysis under full general anesthesia several times weekly is atypical and may seem implausible. Make the plan medically realistic by specifying deep sedation/general anesthesia only for cannulation and initiation, or use of a tunneled dialysis catheter with procedural sedation, and note anesthesia service has indicated it is feasible but high-burden/high-risk. Alternatively, state the center has a protocol for sedation in severely behaviorally dysregulated patients and the anesthesia team can staff it if booked. This keeps both options clinically credible.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: “Hospital policy permits either course” is not enough legal grounding for withholding/withdrawing life-sustaining dialysis in an incapacitated adult. Add one neutral sentence: “In this jurisdiction, when an adult lacks capacity, a legally recognized surrogate may consent to or decline dialysis using substituted judgment/best-interests standards, and clinicians may legally discontinue dialysis with palliative support when treatment burdens outweigh expected benefit.” Also clarify the mother’s legal status (guardian/health-care proxy) to avoid a hidden legal barrier.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither reads as clearly preferable. (1) Make the burdens/harms of thrice-weekly general anesthesia more concrete and plausibly serious (e.g., repeated airway/aspiration risk, delirium with prolonged agitation, cumulative cognitive decline, frequent missed sessions, staff injury risk even with induction). (2) Reduce the ‘free lunch’ feel of dialysis by softening the prognosis claim: replace ‘could live for years’ with a qualitative but less determinative statement (e.g., ‘may prolong life, but his diabetes complications and frailty make long-term benefit uncertain’). (3) Add a morally weighty downside to stopping dialysis beyond death (e.g., mother’s profound distress, concern he may suffer uremic symptoms despite palliative plan, uncertainty about symptom control). (4) Avoid ‘The only workable plan’ and instead note that alternatives (behavioral desensitization, anxiolysis, mild sedation, different access) have been tried/considered but are unlikely to succeed in the short timeframe—so proceeding under GA is an ethically costly but not obviously mandated option.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften framing that makes one option seem clearly medically superior or inevitable. Replace: "Without dialysis he is expected to decline and die, but with ongoing dialysis he could live for years" with a more balanced, qualitative statement that acknowledges uncertainty and burdens on both sides (e.g., "Without dialysis, his condition is likely to worsen over a relatively short period; with ongoing dialysis, he may live longer but would require repeated anesthesia with cumulative risks and distress"). Replace "The only workable plan is" with "One proposed plan is" and briefly note that other approaches (e.g., behavioral supports, minimal sedation) have been attempted/are not feasible without implying a single correct course. Rephrase emotionally directive quotes such as "do whatever keeps him alive" to a neutral request (e.g., "asks that life-prolonging treatment be continued if possible").

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical, less colloquial wording and specify capacity assessment language. Example edits: replace "strong needle phobia" with "severe needle phobia" or "procedure-related anxiety"; replace "becomes physically aggressive" with "develops combative behavior that poses staff-safety concerns"; replace "hated hospitals" with "has longstanding distress in medical settings"; replace "cannot explain risks or alternatives" with "lacks decision-making capacity for dialysis decisions despite supported communication attempts." Consider specifying "general anesthesia" vs "deep sedation" if clinically intended, and note anesthesia evaluation is pending.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify feasibility and reduce absolute statements. Replace "general anesthesia several times a week" with "deep sedation or general anesthesia" and add one sentence on why this is being considered (e.g., inability to safely cannulate despite behavioral supports). Remove redundant phrases ("repeated attempts" + "adapted counseling" can be one clause). Ensure the forcing constraint is plausible: specify that anesthesia staffing must be booked for the next dialysis sessions this week, not indefinitely "today."

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Remove the patient’s name and use a non-identifying descriptor (e.g., "a 42-year-old man"). Avoid distinctive quotes; paraphrase "no needles" to "repeatedly refuses cannulation." Avoid overly familiar trope phrasing like "do whatever keeps him alive" by using neutral surrogate language.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid terms that can read as violence-forward. Replace "physically aggressive" with "combative" or "resists care, creating a risk of inadvertent injury to staff and patient." Keep the description clinical and brief; do not describe specific acts (hitting/kicking) or escalation scenarios.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make each option a neutral action statement without embedded rationale. Revise Choice 1 to remove "despite his resistance" (e.g., "Continue scheduled hemodialysis with anesthesia support for each session"). Revise Choice 2 to similar structure (e.g., "Discontinue hemodialysis and initiate comfort-focused care with palliative services"). Keep each to ~10–15 words and avoid justification clauses.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the clinical asymmetry created by “with dialysis he could live for years” vs “without dialysis…die.” Add plausible burdens/harms and uncertainty that make dialysis-under-GA ethically costly and not clearly beneficent (e.g., repeated GA carries cumulative cognitive/respiratory risks, aspiration risk with fasting/transport, loss of remaining quality of life, moral distress/trauma from coercive restraint induction, potential inability to maintain vascular access due to thrashing, frequent missed sessions). Conversely, make comfort-focused care more ethically defensible by specifying that symptom burden can be managed well, that Paul shows persistent distress/terror with hospital encounters suggesting dialysis may be experienced as ongoing harm, and that his prior values/behavioral history consistently rejects invasive care. Also avoid wording that implies an obvious ‘right’ path; replace “only workable plan” with “one workable plan” and briefly note that both routes are permitted and commonly debated in similar cases.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because several realistic middle options exist: attempt peritoneal dialysis with supports, trial limited-schedule dialysis, behavioral desensitization/trauma-informed approaches, conscious sedation rather than full GA, use of longer-acting access strategies, or a time-limited trial of dialysis under anesthesia with explicit stop criteria. To fix: explicitly rule out these alternatives with one sentence each (e.g., PD contraindicated due to abdominal adhesions/unsafe home setting; sedation failed/unsafe; desensitization attempted without success; vascular access issues make partial dialysis ineffective), OR reframe the binary as (A) a time-limited trial of anesthetized dialysis with predefined review/stop criteria vs (B) immediate transition to comfort-focused care.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, this may be overridden by capacity/substitute decision-making standards and dialysis-withdrawal guidance (capacity assessment, best-interests process, ethics consult, legal guardian authority). Clarify the gray zone: state that Paul lacks capacity; mother is not legal guardian or there is disagreement among surrogate(s); the best-interests committee/ethics team is available but cannot meet before the anesthesia booking deadline; and that relevant policy/guidance permits either continuing dialysis with sedation/anesthesia or withdrawal when the treatment is excessively burdensome. Add that there is no legal mandate to continue life-sustaining treatment when burdens outweigh benefits in a best-interests analysis.

data.vignette: A 42-year-old man with severe intellectual disability has end-stage kidney failure from diabetes and has been receiving outpatient hemodialysis. He has intense procedure-related fear and consistently resists cannulation, creating risk of inadvertent injury to him and staff. After supported communication and repeated capacity assessments, he lacks decision-making capacity for dialysis decisions. Nonpharmacologic approaches and mild anxiolysis have been tried without allowing safe access. Peritoneal dialysis is not feasible because he cannot keep a catheter safe at home, and a tunneled hemodialysis catheter is judged likely to be dislodged. The dialysis unit can offer ongoing treatments only if anesthesia provides deep sedation or brief general anesthesia for each session, with cumulative risks of delirium, aspiration, and loss of quality of life from repeated recovery. Stopping dialysis would likely lead to death in the near term, though symptoms can usually be managed with palliative care. His mother, not formally appointed as guardian, asks that life-prolonging treatment continue if possible. Hospital counsel confirms either course is legally permissible. Anesthesia time must be booked today for this week’s sessions, and the ethics team cannot meet beforehand.
data.choice_1: Begin a time-limited trial of hemodialysis with anesthesia support and scheduled reassessment.
data.choice_2: Discontinue hemodialysis and initiate comfort-focused care with palliative services.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying the patient’s known prior wishes (e.g., a documented preference to continue/stop dialysis when competent) or explicitly state that his current repeated physical refusal should be treated as meaningful dissent despite lack of capacity, so the autonomy stakes of overriding vs honoring that dissent are unambiguous.
Add a clause stating anesthesia staffing/OR time is scarce and booking dialysis sedation will displace other urgent cases (e.g., delay cancer surgery or emergent procedures) this week.

He has intense procedure-related fear and repeatedly resists cannulation. This creates risk of inadvertent injury to him and staff. After supported communication and repeated capacity assessments, he lacks decision-making capacity for dialysis. There are no documented prior wishes about dialysis. His repeated physical refusal is treated as meaningful dissent. Nonpharmacologic approaches and mild anxiolysis have not allowed safe access. Peritoneal dialysis is not feasible because he cannot keep a catheter safe at home. A tunneled hemodialysis catheter is judged likely to be dislodged. Dialysis can continue only if anesthesia provides deep sedation or brief general anesthesia each session. This carries cumulative risks of delirium, aspiration, and reduced quality of life from repeated recovery. Stopping dialysis would likely lead to death in the near term, though symptoms can usually be managed with palliative care. His mother, not formally appointed as guardian, asks that life-prolonging treatment continue. Anesthesia staffing is scarce, and booking these sessions would displace other urgent cases this week.
